newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan-Swearingen venture boosts capital to $95m.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan-Swearingen venture boosts capital to $95m.

text.p: Taiwan's first aviation venture with a U.S. company will more than double its capital to US$95 million for operation needs, the island's aviation committee said on Friday.

"Taiwan's partners in Sino-Swearingen have agreed to increase the venture's capital by US$50 million to US$95 million," an official at the Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development said to Reuters by telephone.
"Sino-Swearingen's initial capital of US$45 million will be used up by the end of this year, and it urgently needs more money for operations," he said.
Taiwan's government has a small stake in the venture through its minority stake in Taiwan Aerospace Corp, which leads a group of six Taiwan partners jointly holding half of the venture.

In January 1995, the six Taiwan partners agreed with U.S.-based Swearigen Aircraft Inc to set up Sino-Swearingen. The joint-venture company will make six-seat SJ-30 passenger jets in the United States.
Swearington holds half of the joint-venture company.
The company is expected to finish constructing an aircraft plant in West Virginia by September 1997, the official said.
"Sino-Swearingen has received orders for 68 planes and will start to sell planes from November 1998," he said.
The six Taiwan firms are Taiwan Aerospace Corp, President Enterprises, United Microelectronics, Tuntex, the Chinfon Group and an unlisted glass firm.
Taiwan Aerospace, which is 29 percent owned by the Taiwan government, was founded in 1991 as the main vehicle to develop the island's fledgling aerospace industry.
Sino-Swearingen is its first step towards realising its goal of building a domestic aerospace industry.
